notes.title: Chapter 5: Principles of Inheritance and Variation
notes.description: This chapter explains how traits are inherited from parents to offspring, the laws of inheritance discovered by Mendel, and the various patterns of genetic expression such as incomplete dominance, codominance, multiple allelism, linkage, and chromosomal disorders.

sections.content: Introduction

Genetics is the branch of biology that deals with heredity and variation. Heredity is the process of passing traits from parents to offspring, while variation refers to the differences observed among individuals of the same species.

sections.meaning: The transmission of genetic characters from parents to their offspring.
Differences among individuals of the same species or population.

sections.content: Gregor Johann Mendel – Father of Genetics

items: Mendel performed experiments on garden pea (Pisum sativum).
He selected seven contrasting traits like tall/dwarf, round/wrinkled, yellow/green, etc.
Used pure line or true-breeding plants.
Published his findings in 1865 – 'Experiments on Plant Hybridisation'.

sections.content: Mendel's experiments formed the foundation of modern genetics and introduced the concept of 'factors' now known as genes.
Mendel’s Experiments
1️⃣ Monohybrid Cross
A monohybrid cross involves a single pair of contrasting traits. Example: Tall (TT) × Dwarf (tt).
2️⃣ Dihybrid Cross
A dihybrid cross involves two pairs of contrasting traits. Example: Round Yellow (RRYY) × Wrinkled Green (rryy).

sections.title: Dihybrid Cross Ratio
rows: 9 Round Yellow : 3 Round Green : 3 Wrinkled Yellow : 1 Wrinkled Green

sections.content: Mendel’s Laws of Inheritance

items: Law of Dominance – In a pair of contrasting traits, only one is expressed (dominant), while the other remains hidden (recessive).
Law of Segregation – Alleles separate during gamete formation, ensuring gametes are pure.
Law of Independent Assortment – Genes for different traits assort independently during gamete formation.

sections.content: Important Genetic Terms

sections.title: Key Genetic Terms
rows: Unit of inheritance controlling one character.
Alternate forms of a gene (e.g., T and t).
Allele that expresses itself in heterozygous condition.
Allele expressed only in homozygous condition.
Offspring from a cross between different parents.

sections.content: Test Cross
A test cross is made between an F₁ hybrid (Tt) and a recessive parent (tt) to determine the genotype of the F₁ individual.
If all offspring are tall, the F₁ is homozygous; if 50% are tall and 50% dwarf, it is heterozygous.
Incomplete Dominance
In incomplete dominance, neither allele is completely dominant. The heterozygote shows an intermediate phenotype.
Example: Snapdragon (Antirrhinum majus) — Red (RR) × White (rr) → F₁: Pink (Rr).
Codominance
In codominance, both alleles express themselves equally in the heterozygote.
Example: ABO Blood Group – Iᴬ and Iᴮ are codominant; both are expressed in AB blood group.
Multiple Allelism
A gene may have more than two allelic forms in a population. Example: ABO blood group has three alleles – Iᴬ, Iᴮ, and i.
Sex Determination
Linkage
Genes located on the same chromosome are said to be linked and tend to be inherited together.
Linkage was discovered by T.H. Morgan in Drosophila (fruit fly).
Crossing Over
Crossing over is the exchange of gene segments between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes during Prophase I of meiosis. It results in recombination or new gene combinations.
Sex-Linked Inheritance

items: Genes located on sex chromosomes show sex-linked inheritance.
Examples: Colour blindness and Haemophilia are X-linked recessive disorders.

sections.content: Mutation

items: A mutation is a sudden change in the DNA sequence or gene.
Gene mutation – Change in a single gene (e.g., Sickle Cell Anaemia).
Chromosomal mutation – Change in chromosome structure or number.

sections.content: Sickle Cell Anaemia
Sickle Cell Anaemia is caused by a point mutation in the gene coding for the β-chain of haemoglobin. The amino acid glutamic acid is replaced by valine.
Pedigree Analysis
Pedigree analysis is the study of inheritance of traits across several generations in a family. It helps to identify the mode of inheritance (dominant, recessive, or sex-linked).
Pedigree charts are useful for genetic counselling and detecting carriers of genetic disorders.
Chromosomal Disorders

sections.title: Common Chromosomal Disorders in Humans
rows: Mental retardation, short stature, flat face
Missing one X chromosome in females

sections.content: Summary

items: Mendel is known as the Father of Genetics.
He proposed three laws: Dominance, Segregation, and Independent Assortment.
Variations occur due to crossing over, recombination, and mutation.
Genetic disorders are of two types: gene-linked and chromosomal-linked.

sections.content: Understanding inheritance helps in genetic counselling, disease prediction, and improvement of crops and animals.
